* *
Precision: 16 *
Scale: 2 *
Rounding Mode: {@linkplain RoundingMode#HALF_EVEN} *
Locale: JVM Default *
Style: {@linkplain NumberStyle#CURRENCY} * * Fits within the Sybase (and MS SQL Server) money type which is (19,4). Typically you have {@linkplain #QUANTITY}x {@linkplain #PRICE} = {@linkplain #AMOUNT}, an alternative is {@linkplain #QUANTITY} x {@linkplain #PRICE} ={@linkplain #QUANTITY}.
* 'datetime' and/or 'timestamp' as in {@linkplain #DATE} and {@linkplain #TIME}.
* *
Precision: 7 *
Scale: 3 *
Rounding Mode: {@linkplain RoundingMode#HALF_EVEN} *
Locale: JVM Default *
Style: {@linkplain NumberStyle#GENERAL} *
* *

Locale: JVM Default *
Style: {@linkplain NumberStyle#GENERAL} *
* *

* *

* *

* Price or conversion rate (foreign exchange rate). * *
Precision: 16 *
Scale: 8 *
Rounding Mode: {@linkplain RoundingMode#HALF_EVEN} *
Locale: JVM Default *
Style: {@linkplain NumberStyle#GENERAL} * * Typically you have {@linkplain #QUANTITY} x {@linkplain #PRICE} = {@linkplain #AMOUNT}, an alternative is{@linkplain #QUANTITY} x {@linkplain #PRICE} = {@linkplain #QUANTITY}.
* *
Precision: 16 *
Scale: 6 *
Rounding Mode: {@linkplain RoundingMode#HALF_EVEN} *
Locale: JVM Default *
Style: {@linkplain NumberStyle#GENERAL} * * Typically you have {@linkplain #QUANTITY} x {@linkplain #PRICE} = {@linkplain #AMOUNT}, an alternative is{@linkplain #QUANTITY} x {@linkplain #PRICE} = {@linkplain #QUANTITY}.
* {@linkplain #getQuantity()} * {@linkplain #getPrice()} = {@linkplain #getAmount()}
